content.description: Two diagrams of tensile test specimens. The left one, labeled 'STD shape (Dog Bone)', shows a dog-bone shaped specimen with a marked 'Gauge length (L,a)' and an arrow pointing to 'used for analysis'. The right one is a simpler rectangular bar labeled 'Normal specimen'.
content.label: Tensile test specimens

content.latex: \sigma_y = \frac{\text{Yield load}}{\text{Original Area}} \qquad \sigma_u = \frac{\text{Ultimate load}}{\text{Original Area}} \qquad \sigma_f = \frac{\text{Fracture load}}{\text{Original Area}}
\text{% increase in length} = \frac{\text{Change in length}}{\text{Original length}} \times 100 = \frac{\text{Final length} - \text{Initial length}}{\text{Initial length}}
\text{% Reduction in Area} = \frac{\text{Change in area}}{\text{Original Area}} = \frac{\text{Original Area} - \text{Finale area}}{\text{Original Area}} \times 100

content.text: Ques:- A mild steel of diameter 12mm, gauge length 60mm is subjected to tensile load, Final length 80mm, final diameter is 7mm, yield load 3.5kN, ultimate load 6.1kN. find the yield stress, ultimate stress, % increase in length and % reduction in length.
